Griet.Action: Pulls her white cap forward and resumes work quietly despite anticipation and fear, showing composure and respect for household rules.
Carefully places her father's best black jacket on the bed and guides his clawed hand gently.
Accepts a tile from her father, a gesture of regret and apology, indicating empathetic understanding.
Attempts to ease her father's coat despite his refusal, showing care.
Continues chopping vegetables quietly while visitors arrive, showing composure and respect.
Tries to ease on her injured father's coat, showing care and attentiveness despite difficulty.
Looks to her mother for guidance and continues chopping vegetables with head bent when visitors arrive, demonstrating composure and diligence under scrutiny.
Carefully arranges vegetables in swathes of colour to please the Man.
Feels startled and instinctively pulls her cap forward when the Man intrudes into her private world.
Controls herself from immediately rearranging vegetables when the Man drops them carelessly, showing restraint and respect.
Deflects Catharina's mocking question about how she spends her time, indicating discomfort and a slight distancing.
Bends to pick up the knife carefully after it falls, showing attentiveness and respect by excusing herself to Master Vermeer.
Holds a wet rag to her mother's burn, a rare moment of physical comfort and care.
Nods dutifully to her mother's advice about keeping clear of the Catholic prayers, showing tolerance and a willingness to listen.
Bends to pick up the spinning kitchen knife carefully, addressing Master Vermeer politely and respectfully in a tense moment.
Neatly folds her laundry and prayer book with care and quietness, tiptoeing so as not to disturb Frans pretending to sleep.
Listens intently and nods dutifully to her mother's cautious and complex advice about navigating the household's religious tensions.
Takes the treasured comb and oat cakes from her mother without protest, indicating acceptance of difficult circumstances and readiness to face challenges.
Hesitates and looks small and lonely in the large square but proceeds onward into the unknown.
Faces silent assessment and smirks from other girls for her clothing and shoes without reacting negatively or with hostility.
Adjusts the bundle under her arm, squares her shoulders, and heads confidently across the large empty square into the unknown.
Appears small and lonely in the huge space and hesitates before crossing.
Surreptitiously straightens the nearest sheet in a messy room.
Surreptitiously straightens the nearest sheet, noticing disorder and responding with a small corrective action.
Appears distracted by the dazzling variety of paintings and surroundings, showing some unfamiliarity or overwhelmed by new environment.
Smiles back at Cornelia when asked if she likes the paintings.
Shows interest and curiosity by asking if Cornelia's father did the paintings.
Feels stupid after Cornelia's scornful response.
Asks Tanneke if she has been doing all the cooking and cleaning herself, showing awareness and willingness to learn about the tasks ahead.
Feels stupid after Cornelia laughs at her misunderstanding about the paintings’ origin.
Smiles back at Cornelia, trying to engage and maintain social composure despite feeling out of place.
Neatly arranges her few possessions and prays before going to sleep despite exhaustion.
Drapes an apron over a disturbing religious painting in the cellar, showing respect or care toward household property.
Works hard washing laundry despite raw fingers and physical discomfort.
Politely greets Catharina with a curtsey and 'Good Morning, Madam'.
Does not respond or argue when Catharina looks annoyed and orders her not to speak until spoken to.
Waits in silence outside the studio and hesitantly enters at Catharina’s order, showing respect and willingness to comply despite discomfort.
Carries out her chores quietly without complaint, indicating patience and a cooperative attitude.
Does not openly challenge Catharina's harshness or restrictions, showing restraint and tolerance.
Takes initiative to enter and begin cleaning the studio despite hesitation and tension, follows instructions carefully.
Responds calmly and respectfully to Catharina's strict and somewhat hostile instructions, showing self-control and understanding of her precarious position.
Waits silently without causing disturbance or acting impulsively in a tense situation inside the studio.
Shows hesitation and uncertainty about entering the studio and starting work, indicating some lack of confidence or skill in this specific task.
Moves from window to window pulling open the heavy wooden shutters to let sunlight flood in, enabling her to work properly.
Carefully inspects and cleans the studio methodically, anchoring her hand to steady herself and using fingers to dust and fix objects.
Recognizes the mirror and pauses, staring at her reflection with a mixture of wonder and embarrassment, then turns away.
Avoids looking at the painting for as long as possible, showing hesitation or reluctance.
Makes reflections dance across the walls for the children to chase.
Looks back at the painting despite being told to keep to herself; studies the painting carefully and makes an insightful comment about the difference in effect.
Responds politely with a curtsey and mumbled 'Madam' when addressed by Maria Thins.
Surprised by Maria Thins’ comment about the painting not being finished, showing limited knowledge about the painting’s progress.
Hurries to gather cleaning things and obeys the order to stop gawping, showing prompt compliance.
Creates reflections with the cleaning of silverware to entertain children, demonstrating creativity and skilled use of her environment.
Stops Lisbeth and Aleydis from making filthy handprints on clean sheets, asserting discipline.
Slaps Cornelia sharply on the cheek for making a dirty handprint, causing shock but no tears.
Points out that the meat is not fresh and insists on better quality for the Mistress.
Looks away from the jaunty calf with effort, showing discomfort with the scene.
Holds chops out stubbornly despite potential awkwardness, standing up for standards rather than conforming silently.
Blushes and tightens grip on the pail when noticed by Pieter, indicating modesty and respect rather than flirtation or arrogance.
Detects that the meat is not fresh and insists on better quality despite social pressure.
Hesitates and looks to Tanneke for guidance when asked what she wants, showing uncertainty.
Approaches the mysterious box cautiously but with curiosity, shows sincere interest despite not understanding.
Jumps back guiltily when Vermeer catches her looking, then quickly apologizes and offers to clean the cloak she dropped.
Approaches the strange camera obscura box cautiously and examines it despite not knowing what it is.
Responds to Vermeer's questions honestly about what she sees, even showing some hesitation but attempts to articulate her observations.
Startled and confused by the unfamiliar experience, but quickly recovers and apologizes to clean immediately.
Initially does not understand the camera obscura and fails to see an image clearly.
Shows genuine fascination and curiosity about Vermeer’s camera obscura and painting process.
Wishes to understand Vermeer’s intentions and tries to follow his instructions carefully.
Startled by the disturbance of the carefully arranged table settings, indicating respect for the household’s order and values.
Hesitates in the doorway while bringing wine after childbirth, showing sensitivity and respect for the family’s intimate moment.
Pumps water quietly despite the distressing cries, showing a willingness to help calmly and dutifully.
Quickly responds to TANNEKE’s request by fetching water from the cistern despite the distressing screams and cold night conditions.
Hides on the cellar steps covering her ears, showing hesitation and discomfort with the birth noises.
Brings wine to the new mother but hesitates in the doorway, indicating some uncertainty or reserve.
Blushes and pulls points of cap forward in response to Van Ruijven's lascivious gaze, then looks down in silence when he eyes her.
Politely declines wine offer with 'No, sir' despite being shocked and trying to hide it.
Pulls the points of her cap forward to cover her blush in response to Van Ruijven's lascivious look, trying to maintain composure.
Looks down in silence and refuses offered wine politely but firmly ('No, sir.'), showing restraint.
Cannot stop herself from blushing at the lascivious gaze, reveals some vulnerability.
Keeps answers brief and does not engage in Van Ruijven's provocations.
Looks at the painting, drinking in the detail, fascinated.
Shakes her head when offered wine again.
Takes a step back when Van Ruijven leans too close.
Looks at the painting closely, noticing fine details and absorbing the description with fascination.
Takes a step back when Van Ruijven leans in too close, showing awareness and boundaries.
Assists Tanneke diligently in the kitchen, helps prepare for celebration despite the harsh conditions.
Scrubs front door step furiously to prepare the house for guests and celebration, including taking care of fine christening robes.
Takes the letter carefully from Van Ruijven’s hot sealing wax as instructed.
Assists Tanenke in the smoky kitchen despite the difficult conditions.
Scours the front doorstep with furious energy and repeats the cleaning despite men tracking mud inside.
Refuses to smile at Pieter despite his teasing, shows tiredness but eventually gives a small smile.
Hides her cracked and bleeding hand under her apron rather than complain or seek help.
Silently observes Pieter and Vermeer interaction, biting her lip, showing restraint and respect.
Re-fills wine jugs and serves guests quietly during a busy party.
Re-fills wine jugs and serves wine at the banquet, helping the household and guests.
Serves wine at a formal banquet calmly and efficiently.
Pours wine quietly as directed by Catharina during tense moments, contributing to a calm and hospitable atmosphere.
Pours wine calmly and dutifully during the tense painting appraisal moment, responding to CATHARINA's subtle cue without disrupting the atmosphere.
Refills Van Ruijven’s glass when signaled by Maria Thins, performing her duties quietly and without complaint.
Experiences inner turmoil and discomfort when Van Ruijven touches her arm and directs attention toward her, yet maintains composure.
Quietly leaves the noisy room without complaint, showing consideration for others' distress.
Observes the bailiffs and the distressed family with wide eyes, indicating empathy and sensitivity.
Listens quietly and receptively to Tanneke's story about Catharina's outburst without judgment.
Lingers thoughtfully by the dying embers of the kitchen fire after others have gone to bed, showing reflective calmness.
Meets Vermeer's eyes briefly and respectfully then looks down, showing a mixture of deference and sincerity.
Returns home to the poorer quarter without complaint, accepting her circumstances.
Kneels in church beside family members, exhibiting traditional familial affection and community participation.
Listens quietly and attentively to the servants' conversation about household troubles, showing awareness of social tensions.
Responds to Vermeer entering quietly by looking down and avoiding eye contact, demonstrating social sensitivity and self-control.
Presents herself in her best lace collar when receiving coins from Maria Thins, displaying an understanding of social appearances and propriety.
Returns calmly to her poorer quarter, maintaining composure in a lower social environment.
Introduces Pieter to her family politely despite feeling annoyed at her mother's and Pieter's knowing smiles.
Refuses to be impressed by Pieter's charm and cleverness, speaking to him frankly.
Accepts Pieter’s offered arm and holds her head up confidently while walking away, not shying from social attention.
Refuses to be impressed by Pieter's flattery, responds with a sharp retort 'You had nothing better to do.'
Takes Pieter's arm and holds her head high as they walk away despite the gossips watching, maintaining composure and confidence.
Appears annoyed at the knowing smile passed between her mother and Pieter but does not engage negatively, managing her emotions subtly.
Answers Pieter's smile with her own despite folded arms.
Offers to clean the windows to improve the studio light, showing consideration for others' work.
Does not insist or argue when Catharina rolls her eyes and responds sharply, showing tolerance and restraint.
Tries awkwardly to continue wiping windows after Vermeer orders her to stop, showing deference and respect.
Considers the effect of cleaning windows on light in the studio before acting.
Takes initiative to clean the windows without explicit instruction, showing awareness of her environment's impact on work.
Immediately stops cleaning and follows Vermeer’s instructions precisely, showing obedience but also attentiveness.
Hesitates and awkwardly reacts to Vermeer’s presence, indicating some uncertainty.
Hurries to pick up papers that Catharina drops, showing attentiveness and care.
Hesitates and bows head when asked if she can read, showing modesty and deference.
Tenses when the baby stops crying, indicating sensitivity and concern.
Is given the errand to the apothecary, an unusual and disliked task, but accepts it without complaint (implied).
Takes down laundry outside in the cold with patience and care despite discomfort.
Responds promptly and respectfully when called by Catharina, showing attentiveness.
Hurries to pick up papers that fell when Catharina pushes them aside, showing quickness and conscientiousness.
Hesitates when asked if she can read and admits she can only follow her prayer book, revealing limited literacy skill.
Accepts the unlikely errand of going to the apothecary despite surprise and implied inexperience, demonstrating willingness but possible uncertainty.
Wraps her woollen shawl tightly and goes to get medicines despite the bitter cold, showing care for the children.
Quickly evades Cornelia's questions with a lie to hide the secret purchase for Vermeer.
Realizes there is not enough money but still obtains the note to get supplies on the Master's account, showing resourcefulness and discretion.
Responds calmly and carefully when confronted by Cornelia's suspicion, evading the question with a plausible excuse without arousing open conflict.
Tucks the note into her shawl quickly but not quickly enough to avoid being noticed by Cornelia, indicating a momentary lapse in subtlety.
Politely delivers a note from her Mistress and calmly handles the Apothecary's suspicion without complaint.
Keeps her expression blank and does not reveal true thoughts when the Apothecary frowns and questions her.
Approaches the apothecary confidently, presents the note from her Mistress, and responds calmly to the apothecary's suspicion about delivering pigments in bad weather.
Does not try to explain beyond a simple reason for her delivery (weather), possibly appearing evasive but maintaining composure under scrutiny.
Stares with fascination at the apothecary's pigments, showing sincere appreciation for quality materials.
Startled but polite response to Maria Thins' sharp pinning of cloth and questions.
Mops the floor diligently and accepts Maria Thins' reprimand without complaint.
No direct interaction with Cornelia's scowl or Maria Thins' softening; remains passive.
Notices that her belongings have been deliberately disturbed and tile broken, but no indication of confrontation or complaint.
Stares at the mysterious raw materials of magic (pigments) with interest but no indication of understanding yet.
Is attentive and aware of the new painting Vermeer has started, responding promptly and respectfully to Maria Thins' inquiry.
Mopping the floor on hands and knees diligently, despite being pinched by Maria Thins' cane, showing carefulness and resilience.
Not reacting defensively or sulking when Cornelia scowls after being forced to redo the floor, maintaining composure and responsibility.
Her personal belongings disturbed and broken deliberately in the cellar, indicating an external threat rather than incompetence.
Tells Cornelia she will spoil the lacework by teasing the kitten, tries to protect delicate work
Angrily tells Cornelia to pick up the scattered pins and bobbins, stands up to Cornelia’s defiance
Withdraws to the studio to escape hostility, apologizes politely to Vermeer
Does not escalate conflict further with Cornelia or retaliate beyond standing up to her
Measures out white paste and quietly takes initiative to find a pigment she thinks suitable for the painting.
Does not argue or protest when Vermeer coldly rejects the blue pigment she chose, quietly putting it away.
Tries to push away Pieter’s physical advances and firmly rejects his attempts to see her hair, beating at his arms seriously to maintain boundaries.
Cleans the picture setting carefully, Buffs the silver jug and compares the setting to the painting attentively.
Blurts out her confusion honestly when she does not understand the colours in the painting.
Initially answers incorrectly about the colour of the clouds but self-corrects herself with more thoughtful observation.
Feels intimidated and dares not speak freely at times in presence of Vermeer, showing some hesitation.
Blushes when teased by Tanneke about her feelings, laughs not unkindly
Brings the apothecary packages to Vermeer without complaint
Expresses fear and hesitation but still tries to meet Vermeer’s artistic demands
Voices concerns about chores but is willing to make time to help Vermeer
Quietly slips away from the market to the apothecary's shop and brings Vermeer the lapis lazuli pigment.
Eager but hesitant when Vermeer instructs her to mix colors, expressing concern about her chores.
Overcomes hesitation and climbs the ladder into the attic studio to assist Vermeer despite uncertainty.
Watches Vermeer patiently and with fascination as he explains pigments.
Tries to grind pigment as Vermeer instructs, showing willingness to learn.
Reacts by recoiling abruptly and dropping the muller after Vermeer touches her hand.
Watches Vermeer carefully and attempts to grind pigment as he demonstrates, though awkwardly at first.
Freezes and recoils when Vermeer touches her hand, losing control of the muller.
Sneaks quietly through the house before dawn to avoid disturbing others.
Quietly folds linen without complaint despite feeling tension and being the subject of disdain.
Displays patience and restraint in a hostile domestic atmosphere without direct confrontation.
Remains passive and frozen while others decide her fate, showing no visible assertiveness or engagement.
Wakes early with a sense of freedom and carefully lays out her few precious things including a prayer book before starting work.
Inspects the painting critically and frowns, indicating sincere care and attentiveness to her work and surroundings.
Passes by CATHARINA without looking up, only murmuring an acknowledgement with eyes down.
Wakes early, organizes her few belongings carefully, and prepares pigment with skill and ease, showing smooth, trance-like efficiency.
Inspects the painting critically, discerning that something is not right and thoughtfully blocking parts with her hands to analyze the composition.
Leaves the studio quietly with eyes down, showing deference but not asserting herself in a social setting.
Watches Vermeer and Van Leeuwenhoek quietly from the attic without interrupting their work.
Hides promptly when Van Leeuwenhoek notices her presence, avoiding confrontation.
Grinds pigment smoothly and easily, showing skill and calm focus like Vermeer.
Freezes when men enter the studio unexpectedly, indicating cautious awareness.
Peers down into the studio quietly without being immediately noticed, showing discretion and observational skill.
Hides effectively when discovered by Van Leeuwenhoek, avoiding confrontation or trouble.
Hesitates but then answers Van Leeuwenhoek honestly about grinding pigments, despite it being a secret with Vermeer.
Smiles (lips curl upwards) at Van Leeuwenhoek's playful antics under Vermeer's cloak.
Tries to look solemn to obey Vermeer's sharp command to stop smiling and not spoil the picture.
Responds confidently to Van Leeuwenhoek's question about grinding pigments, maintaining her secret with Vermeer while gaining confidence from Van Leeuwenhoek's demeanor.
Takes up the model's pose uncertainly when asked by Vermeer, showing some hesitation in fulfilling the task.
Suppresses laughter and tries to look solemn when Vermeer admonishes her, showing self-control and ability to follow instructions even under pressure.
Holds her breath and remains silent when Vermeer turns away, showing emotional restraint and awareness of her position in the household and social context.
Speaks kindly to Tanneke about wanting children, showing genuine curiosity and concern.
Hurries to leave when reprimanded by Maria Thins, showing obedience but no open confrontation or hostility.
Remains in the painting pose quietly despite witnessing the tense family scene, showing composure and awareness.
Hurries to leave immediately when ordered downstairs by Maria Thins, demonstrating quick obedience but possibly lack of assertiveness.
Engages thoughtfully with Tanneke about sensitive topics such as pregnancy and family, showing emotional intelligence and reflective thinking.
Is visibly surprised and cannot hide her emotions regarding family news, indicating some naïveté or lack of experience.
Playfully runs away from Pieter and allows him to kiss her.
Lays out colours for the day with absolute certainty and precision, showing care and dedication to her work.
Carefully and deliberately moves the heavy chair out of the painting’s foreground, showing boldness but also respect for the art.
Is wrong-footed and tries to keep calm when Cornelia accuses her.
Lays out colours for the day with absolute certainty and precision, glances at the painting to be sure of what is needed.
Carefully and deliberately moves the heavy lion-headed chair out of the painting’s foreground, showing boldness in altering the setting.
Does not attempt to guess TANNEKE’s age, wisely avoiding a risky or potentially embarrassing mistake.
Is wrong-footed and surprised when CORNELIA catches her moving the chair and faces an accusation, tries to keep calm but is unsettled.
Admits to Vermeer that she did not take the comb and asks for his help quietly and sincerely.
Stays silent and does not retaliate or escalate accusations despite Catharina’s harsh accusations and the household uproar.
Looks towards Vermeer hoping for defense when falsely accused by Catharina.
Does not respond or defend herself against harsh accusations publicly.
Stands quietly while being unfairly accused, looks toward Vermeer for defense, maintains composure under pressure.
Does not speak up or defend herself against accusations of sneaking and slacking.
Helps Maertge into her first grown-up dress, making her look like a lady.
Helps Maertge into her first grown-up dress, effectively managing the task so Maertge appears lady-like and proud.
Goes round to serve VAN RUIJVEN, head down, shoulders hunched, trying to be invisible.
Goes round to serve Van Ruijven with head down, shoulders hunched, trying to be invisible.
Rejects gossip and insists she has done nothing wrong when confronted about rumors.
Responds firmly and angrily to Pieter’s warning, asserting her own agency and refusing to be controlled.
Defends herself calmly against gossip and false accusations.
Stuffs meat hastily while agitated, showing some emotional disturbance.
Responds firmly and articulately to Pieter despite social pressure, asserting her own boundaries.
Avoids engaging in gossip and refuses to be drawn into conflicts unnecessarily.
Turns away slowly from Van Ruijven after seeing him with Vermeer, showing discomfort and restraint.
Hurries into the house after Van Ruijven’s inappropriate comments, avoiding further engagement.
Allows herself to be painted alone by Vermeer despite feeling foreboding and sadness, responds with quiet gratitude ('Thank you, sir').
Looks bleakly at the musical instruments, seems emotionally vulnerable and sincere.
Inquires about Master van Ruijven respectfully in presence of Maria Thins, showing a careful, considerate attitude.
No evidence of coldness, hostility or selfishness; mostly silent, humble, and yielding in these scenes.
Waits expectantly for instructions from Vermeer, showing patience and awareness of the situation.
Expresses uncertainty about what to do with the musical instruments, asking 'What should I...(pretend to play)?'
Maintains composure under emotional strain as Vermeer prepares to paint her alone, quietly accepting the situation and saying, 'Thank you, sir.'
Asks Maria Thins pragmatic questions about the painting's fate and Master van Ruijven, showing practical concern and intelligence.
Looks down at the coins in her hands, a subtle sign of internal conflict or hesitation.
Hesitates with heart racing but firmly declines Vermeer's invitation to meet, citing work responsibilities.
Bravely points out that the items in the studio are ladies' things, showing honesty and straightforwardness.
Refuses to wear Catharina's yellow bodice, showing a respectful boundary and sincerity.
Remains silent when Vermeer asks what he should paint her as, indicating possible reserve or reluctance.
Hesitates but clearly asserts she cannot comply with Vermeer's request due to her work, showing self-awareness and boundaries.
Bravely points out that the items around her are 'ladies’ things,' demonstrating observation and speaking up despite the tension.
Plucks up courage to refuse wearing Catharina's clothes despite Vermeer's pressure, indicating moral strength and clear communication.
Does not answer when Vermeer asks what she should be painted as, possibly showing hesitation or uncertainty in a difficult situation.
Adjusts her position patiently to Vermeer’s instructions without complaint.
Stares mostly at the floor, avoiding Vermeer’s gaze, showing humility and restraint.
Silent, reserved presence in the background as Catharina shows jealousy.
Reaches up on tiptoe to get a dish, showing attentiveness and control in her movements.
Adjusts her position as requested by Vermeer, demonstrating responsiveness and composure.
Looks downward and avoids Vermeer's gaze, suggesting some uncertainty or discomfort.
Follows Vermeer's instructions patiently and holds a difficult pose for a long time despite discomfort.
Refuses to remove her cap initially, showing a boundary and protecting her modesty.
Releases her hair and wraps it with cloth in the storeroom, revealing a private, vulnerable side.
Stays silent and hidden behind the wardrobe door during uncomfortable conversation, pressing her face against the linen.
Folds and carefully handles the fine clothing with attention and care, staying still and quiet during a tense conversation, indicating awareness and composure.
Stays dead still behind the wardrobe door, managing to remain unnoticed during a potentially uncomfortable situation.
Listens in terror to Van Ruijven's lewd talk about Vermeer and young women alone.
Endures the strain of holding a difficult pose for the painting with twisted turban, showing dedication and patience.
Listens in terror to suggestive conversation, showing inner fear but no direct response.
Invents and wears a unique 'turban-like head gear' for the painting, showing creativity and initiative.
Trembles with the strain of holding her twisted pose during the painting session.
Says she does not think Vermeer would hurt her despite caution from Van Leeuwenhoek.
Chops vegetables quietly and with reflection before sweeping the pattern into the pot.
Brings in wine jug and glasses to the great hall, attends without complaint.
Follows Vermeer’s uncomfortable instructions in the studio despite horror and hesitation.
Refuses to have her ears pierced despite Vermeer's insistence, standing firm on her boundaries.
Expresses anger and frustration instead of compliance or submission.
Hurries along streets with head down and shawl tight, suggesting withdrawal and possibly distrust or discomfort.
Offers to pay the old man for medicine despite discomfort, showing honesty and trustworthiness.
Hides her attempt to self-treat her earlobe puncture in secret, showing vulnerability but also a desire to protect others from worry.
Says nothing to Maria Thins when confronted about the situation, showing restraint and possibly respect.
Struggles silently and is terrified when Van Ruijven pins her arms, showing vulnerability but no active friendly or warm response.
Struggles against Van Ruijven’s unwanted advances, showing resistance and fear.
Looks to Cornelia for help, silently pleading with her eyes.
Does not verbally confront or retaliate aggressively beyond struggling; maintains a silent suffering.
Struggles against Van Ruijven's assault, tries to resist physically despite fear and danger.
Looks away and hides her face when confronted, showing fear and lack of direct confrontation.
Desperately searches for help and tries to communicate silently with Cornelia.
Fails to secure help as Cornelia deliberately ignores her and walks away.
Manages to free one arm and claw at Van Ruijven's face, showing resourcefulness and fighting spirit.
Accepts and appreciates the hand-made lace collar from the children, thanks them sincerely.
Pulls off the lace collar when encouraged by children to wear it, citing work responsibilities.
Reluctantly takes the pearl earrings from Maria Thins to obey instructions.
Slides her finger through fine-ground rose madder, indicating familiarity and comfort with painter's materials.
Pours water into the copper with deliberate movements despite physical weakness from bruises.
Responds quickly when grabbed from behind, prepared to defend herself, showing alertness and readiness.
Politely thanks children for handmade gift and considers wearing lace collar but refuses to indulge, prioritizing work over appearance.
Removes the lace collar despite encouragement, demonstrating prioritization and self-control.
Reluctantly takes pearl earrings from velvet box when instructed, showing obedience but also hesitation, possibly indicating awareness of risks.
Kisses Pieter passionately, showing affection and emotional openness.
Declines Pieter's offer to run away and marry him, calmly explaining she must return.
Gently puts a hand on Pieter's cheek and kisses him before walking away, showing tenderness and sincerity.
Drops earrings into Maria Thins' hand without comment, indicating acceptance of her difficult position without complaint.
Cleans the studio silently and alone, avoiding her paintings, reflecting introspection and possibly emotional restraint.
Meets Pieter’s eyes levelly and calmly refuses to run away with him despite his pleading and offers, showing self-control and clear-headedness.
Reties her cap and adjusts her clothing carefully after an intimate moment, maintaining composure in a delicate situation.

Avoids looking at the paintings in the studio, covering her own painting and steering clear of the unfinished Concert painting, indicating inner conflict and possible avoidance rather than confronting her feelings or ambitions.
Maintains calm and steady eye contact with Vermeer during Catharina's outburst, showing composure.
Does not verbally defend herself or try to escalate the conflict despite accusations and tension.
Appears passive and silent in the face of Catharina's anger and accusations, potentially indicating a lack of assertiveness.
Quietly leaves the house carrying her bundle without confrontation, not looking back.
Carries her small bundle and leaves the Vermeer house alone, without looking back, showing determination and self-control in a difficult moment.
Listens silently outside the closed studio door but does not attempt to force entry or call out, possibly indicating restraint or passivity.
Accepts a thoughtful gift (the pearl earrings) from Tanneke with gratitude and quiet reflection.
Offers to see Tanneke to the bridge despite Tanneke declining, showing politeness and consideration.
Gently receives the package from Tanneke, carefully handles it with restraint, and quietly contemplates the pearl earrings with deep emotion.
Does not openly react or make any impulsive decisions upon receiving the earrings; instead, she controls her emotions and responds with calm politeness to Tanneke.
